page.title: 02LANDSCAPE IN CRUWYS MORCHARD
page.content: Cruwys Morchard offers a landscape of small hedged and banked meadows of irregular shape, interspersed with patches of broadleaved woodland, on gently undulating hills and small steep valleys eroded by the action of streams. Rainfall is high and the grass stays green through most of the year. Most farms are isolated, set in sheltered positions on the slopes of hills where water is available. The pattern of the fields and covers indicates ancient clearances from the natural woodland. One hamlet, Pennymoor, is set on a ridge at 239m while Church and Manor House are more sheltered at 220m. The settlements and farms are connected by a network of narrow highbanked lanes, with only one main road, the A373, added in the 19c.
